title: Biomimetic UAV Flocking for Active Wildlife Deterrence: A Magnetodynamic Approach
authors: **Finn Wilson**, Sarah Chen, Dr. Michael Roberts
abstract:
This study presents a novel framework for UAV-based wildlife deterrence using a biomimetic approach inspired by predator flocking behavior. Unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) acting in coordinated swarms have shown promise for non-lethal wildlife management in agricultural and airport settings, but existing methods often use naive pursuit strategies that wildlife quickly habituate to. We propose a magnetodynamic framework that models UAV swarm behavior after wolf pack hunting tactics, allowing for more natural and unpredictable engagement patterns.

Field tests conducted at Sydney International Airport demonstrated approximately 91% effectiveness in bird dispersal using our biomimetic algorithm, compared to approximately 65% with traditional pursuit methods. The system dynamically adjusts UAV positioning based on flock responses, creating an adaptive deterrence pattern that maintains effectiveness over time. 

Our implementation includes a physics-based simulation environment and a high-performance C++ swarm control toolkit that addresses limitations in existing Python-based solutions. These tools enable real-time state estimation and coordinated control of the UAV swarm, even under challenging environmental conditions. The framework has potential applications in aviation safety, agriculture, and wildlife management contexts where humane deterrence methods are required.

title: Adaptive Sampling for Resource Characterization: Optimizing Geological Survey Efficiency Using Machine Learning
authors: Dr. James Carter, **Finn Wilson**, Dr. Lisa Zhang, Prof. Robert Johnson
abstract:
This paper introduces a novel adaptive sampling methodology for geological surveying that demonstrates significant cost reductions while maintaining or reducing uncertainty in resource characterization models. Traditional sampling approaches in mining operations often rely on uniform or grid-based patterns that fail to account for the inherent spatial variability of geological properties.

We present a machine learning approach that combines Gaussian Processes and Random Forests to predict ore grade distributions and quantify prediction uncertainty. Our adaptive algorithm iteratively selects new sampling locations to maximize information gain, yielding a 50% improvement in information per sample compared to uniform sampling strategies.

When tested on historical data from an operational mine site in Western Australia, our method achieved over 80% accuracy in ore grade prediction while suggesting a theoretical 40% reduction in required samples to achieve equivalent model confidence. This approach has significant implications for reducing exploration costs and improving resource characterization in mining operations.

The proposed methodology incorporates spatial constraints and practical field considerations, making it immediately applicable to real-world mining scenarios. A companion open-source implementation is provided to facilitate adoption by the mining industry.
